text: I was born in 1953 in Spokane Washington. As a little kid the only team they showed on TV back then was the 49ers. So from my first memories was sitting down every Sunday (When not at church) watching the 49ers with my dad. Then in 1962 we moved to Santa Cruz California (75 miles south of SF). My dad took me to my first football game out at Kezar stadium in the Height area. We saw 49ers VS Rams. All I remember was the rivalry between the fans. There were a few Ram fans and all I remember were a lot of fights. Also went out and saw the Colts with Johnny Unitas. Winning was scarce until The Brodie years (1970-1974). Then along came Walsh in 1978. Me and my buddie put in for season tickets at Candlestick Park in 1979. We got them and had them from 1980 to 1995. Best Tailgate parties in the world. I was there when Clark made "The Catch". That changed everything. One thing about Clark is he was not that fast but I don't think I had seen anyone catch him once he was ahead of someone. He knew how to turn it on. To me the 3 greatest 49ers ever were Montana, Rice and Clark. I guess I would have to include Walsh as the greatest Coach I had ever seen outside of Lombardi. Without Clark I really don't think the 49ers would of been that great until Rice showed up. What a terrible thing to happen to a great person and player. Good luck to Dwight and his family and hopefully someday they can find a cure for this disease..

text:
The author has no clue.  Ban replay altogether because occasionally there is a close call that the author disagrees with?  Every week, replay is used to overturn many obvious bad calls.  A receiver pretends to make a 30-yard catch when the ball skips on the ground -- if no ref is in position to clearly see the ball skip, then we're going to let that "reception" stand?  A punt returner steps out of bounds on his own 25 yard line but the ref doesn't see it, and he goes on to run for 75 more yards and a TD... should that stand?  

The author is probably a millennial who doesn't remember what life was like before replay.  Fans had to watch helplessly as their team would lose a game because the refs didn't see a guy step out of bounds or because they didn't realize a runner was down before he fumbled.  At least now, we can correct the obvious ones.  

As far as the standard of "indisputable" evidence, that's in the eye of the beholder.  Personally, I think the call on the Tate reception was correct, and I understand why they reversed that one.  Yes, I get that there are counter-arguments, but I think they are a reach -- I think the counter-argument is based on someone trying too hard to see something there that isn't there.  When you look at the reception in real time, it's easy to see why the ref might call it a TD, as Tate falls into the end zone.  When you look at it on replay, it's easy to see why they'd conclude he was down by contact at the one-foot line.  I have no problem with the way that played out -- and I'm not a fan of either team involved.  Atlanta fans would've had a legitimate gripe if the TD were allowed to stand; Detroit fans have a gripe that it was overturned.  Personally, I think it was handled appropriately, and I blame the Lions for running a play with no timeouts that had a chance of being short of the goal line.

context_meta.title: An early breakdown of the Yankees' offseason roster
context_meta.summary: The Yankees lost a heartbreaking seven-game series to the Houston Astros, finishing the season just one win shy of their 41st pennant in franchise history. This sucks, and it's understandable if the loss still stings you, but as my good friend Tupac Shakur once said, life goes on. It's time to take the first look at the Yankees' 40-man roster, headed into what's sure to be an eventful offseason. At end of play on Saturday, the Yankees had a full 40-man roster, plus Michael Pineda and Kyle Higashioka on the 60-day DL. This gives us a pool of 42 players who are effectively on the major league roster, and they can be broken down into six buckets: Under contract - those players who will be returning

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Here's What Gordon Hayward Asked Brad Stevens For After His Surgery
context_meta.summary: Gordon Hayward might already be putting shots up less than a week after his surgery. The Boston Celtics star forward underwent surgery to repair his dislocated ankle and fractured tibia last Wednesday, and while the C's were on the road, head coach Brad Stevens reached out to Hayward to ask if he needed anything. His answer: a basketball. Perhaps Hayward already is practicing form shooting from a chair, as Paul George did when he suffered his traumatic leg injury. Either way, it's good to see Hayward is chomping at the bit to get back to the game anyway that he can. Thumbnail photo via John Geliebter/USA TODAY Sports Images
